text: let's assume a person has never heard of dns has never heard of the prague school or any of these things can you in a somewhat succinct but not terribly brief manner explain to people how all of this um school of rehabilitation coalesced around this idea of what we call dns so going back to the founding fathers of the prague school and what these various sort of insights were that each of them had and how that sort of came together okay so um dns or dynamic neuromuscular stabilization kind of built on some pioneers of functional rehabilitation there's many that have been part of the prague school of rehabilitation but i think uh talking about the influence on the development of dynamic neuromuscular stabilization by professor pablo collage who runs the rehabilitation department at prague school at this time i think we need to go back post world war ii cold war era 1950s is where prague school of rehabilitation was was really founded and it was founded as part of the medical faculty of charles university in in prague in the czech republic or formerly czechoslovakia and now czech republic and being post post-world war ii cold war era so they were in eastern europe behind the wall that may have been a factor for their not reliance but tendency towards the use of of observation in both diagnostic diagnosis um both observation and palpation for diagnosis and treatment um all three of these pioneers were neurologists
title: The Prague School of Rehabilitation and the dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS) program

text: and then who who are the three so the three um vladimir yonda carl leavitt and balclavita professor yonda he had a keen sense of observation and he formulated um concepts and principles that tied into postural postural habituation specifically the tendency for specific musculature to tend towards tightness and other musculature to tend towards weakness and he he termed this upper cross and lower cross syndrome so for example with an upper cross syndrome meaning the neck and shoulder region with demands of of life and the tendency towards postural habituation such as with sustained seated postures there's a tendency towards uh the muscles in the back of the neck the occipital muscles the sternocleidomastoid muscle which is the muscle that and also attaches to the skull and down to the sternoclavicular joint the pec muscles the upper traps that musculature would tend towards a tightening or an overactivation other musc musculature in the upper extremity the serratus which attaches to the ribs and in the back of the scapula the deep neck flexors the middle and lower traps would have a tendency to tend towards a weakness and with that tendency towards over utilization or hypertonicity and underutilization inhibition weakness that would also he also recognized that that would affect the quality of movement throughout the kinematic chain and subsequently would lead to
title: The Prague School of Rehabilitation and the dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS) program

text: overload in specific areas throughout that kinematic chain so that was um a big contribution on his part um his colleague where would those places of overload be so if you if you have this tightness in the muscles you've described the weakness in the muscles you've described what is the consequence of that where does that load get distributed right so you with that imbalance and that postural tendency towards postural habituation you would see a tendency to overload in the transitional areas throughout the spine and throughout the extremity so i didn't go into the specifics for lower cross syndrome lower cross syndrome you have a tendency for the flexor hip flexor complex to be overactive tightened so the psoas iliopsoas rectus femoris the uh back extensor musculature will also tend towards tightness and then the weakness or the inhibition will tend toward be towards the lower abdominal region in the gluteal region so looking at it globally you would see a tendency to overload again throughout the extremity throughout the extremities so that the hip joint the knee joint but also specifically dealing with the spine the lumbar sacral region thoracic lumbar region and the cervical thoracic region all the areas where you see the transition of the curvatures lordosis and kyphosis and with that tendency for overload you will get repetitive stresses on the passive structures within that kinematic chain so as a clinician we know that if you tend to image these areas or if you
title: The Prague School of Rehabilitation and the dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS) program

text: image the spine these are the areas that tend to have the most degenerative changes or the most disk pathology and those changes aren't uh aren't usually uh traumatic they're not an acute they're accumulated over time so the the observation of these postural patterns or postural syndromes and then the recognition of the dysfunction with with movement efficiency that it caused led him to develop specific treatments both exercise exercise-wise and manual-wise to it to address those those issues um his colleague carl levitt but yonda also had suffered polio as a as a as a youngster didn't he yeah so he had the suffered the residual effects the post-polio type syndrome and that was probably a motivation for his his passion for rehabilitation his his passion for the observation of movement um his his uh colleague carl levitt also a neurologist he shared that that observation palpation not technique but a tendency to utilize that for diagnosis and treatment he he specifically focused on joint dysfunction soft tissue dysfunction as it related to those those upper and lower cross syndromes so he developed specific mobilization techniques for both the the joint and the soft tissues addressing what they were seeing with those those postural uh postural habituation and movement dysfunction um the third kind of
title: The Prague School of Rehabilitation and the dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS) program

text: pioneer also a neurologist but also a pediatric neurologist with valklav voita and he uh his his observations observing the antigenesis or the development of motor function after birth during the first 12 months where the postural or postural foundations are established neurologically he developed a specific test called postural reactions where he could tell the the quality or the health of the maturation of the central nervous system during that period of time and by doing this he could assess whether there was pathology or a healthy developing central nervous system so he he developed seven specific postural reaction tests developed and modified some other ones utilized primitive reflexes and just observation observation of the infant during development to be able to recognize the biological age meaning the the maturation of that central nervous system as compared to the chronological age so for example if you had a six-month-old infant that was moving and reacting like a six-week-old infant that would be an indication that there was some central nervous system pathology he his focus was on treatment of the cerebral palsy infant and and patient and he was able to utilize that observation those uh observation of the postural reactions the assessment of the primitive reflexes to recognize early on before it would
title: The Prague School of Rehabilitation and the dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS) program

text: manifest clinically so that interventions could be taken earlier on to take advantage of the neuroplasticity the ability of the brain to form motor engrams more efficiently and work around those central lesions that you see with cerebral palsy so he um all three of these uh kind of founding um members or founders of prague school of rehabilitation were professor collage collages colleagues mentors instructors they shared patients they discussed cases and pavel collage developed or evolved all that that knowledge and experience into what we call dynamic neuromuscular stabilization today now before powell came along what was the so so fast forward this started in the 50s but fast forward to the 90s uh so the prague school is well established you have these sort of founding fathers so to speak what were the applications of the prague school at that time how much of it was rehabilitation for kids with cerebral palsy or rehabilitation for people who were injured versus prehabilitation for athletes like what how what was the breadth of the echo applicability of the prog school right so uh prague school uh was it's a group of clinicians and um probably more of the early 90s the application was primarily rehabilitation cerebral palsy general population with uh pavel professor colas just to go in a little bit of his background um you know again he he's the head of prague school of rehabilitation
title: The Prague School of Rehabilitation and the dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS) program

text: he's also head clinician for the czech olympic teams and czech national sports teams hockey soccer men's and women's tennis he himself was a high level olympic level gymnast so um he uh his his work he's a pediatric physiotherapist as well um his work with those three pioneers uh his experience as an athlete his experience treating cerebral palsy and and infants um he took that or started to apply that base of knowledge to the athletic population and the the focus of in the the thinking of these these founders of prague school and and proc school today is it's uh the the influence of the central nervous system is huge and kind of king as far as the uh facilitating the efficiency of transfer of load throughout that kinematic chain so early on the focus was more rehabilitation over multiple populations but maybe late 90s early 2000s pablo started to apply those teachings to that athletic population and um there's meaning to an uninjured athletic population or to an injured athletic population probably at that time more of an injured population two kind of down standout athletes that he was able to work with and integrate his concepts and principles of dynamic stability were uh jean-luc zelezny hopefully i say that right he's a he was a olympic uh javelin thrower three-time gold medal winner still holds the the record for uh javelin 98.48 meters i believe
title: The Prague School of Rehabilitation and the dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS) program
